document.text: Will Work For Modern Highway From Bristol To Norfolk. Lynchburg.The Bristol-to-Norfolk Highway Association was formed in a meeting here, in which sixteen coun ties were represented, the object of which is to work for an east to west modern road crossing the State. It was pointed out that practically the entire route is under contract or con templated, excepting between Roanoke and Farmville. The officers chosen were President Henry Roberts, of Bedford county secretary-treasurer, T. T. Cor- with, Lynchburg vice-presidents, Washington county, A. J. Huff Smythe county, John P. Buchanan Wythe county, E. Lee Trinkle Pulaski county, H. T. Trolinger Mont gomery, Dr. S. W. Fletcher Radford, Judge George E. Caswell Roanoke, .T. A. Turner Roanoke City, J. H. Mar- steller Campbell, John T. McKinney Lynchburg, Ernest Williams Appo mattox, S. L. Ferguson Prince Ed ward, J. L. Hart Nottoway, Joseph M. Hunt Dinwiddle, E. S. Hubbs, and Norfolk county, C. P. Shaw. Other eastern counties will have vice-presidents selected later. The convention by resolution commended the proposed highway and calls upon the press of the State to work for it.

document.text: Whole Business Section And East End Of Melissa Wiped Out. McKinney, Tex.Five persons were killed and from 25 to 50 others in jured, some probably fatally, when a tornado swept down from tho wei.t on Melissa, near here. Fire followed in the debris of the buildings razed by the twister, and virtually the entire business district, except the bank and .he east side of the town, were de stroyed. The tornado unroofed the school building in which about 240 children were at classes, also caving in the east wall, but due to the foresight of the principal and teachers, who, when they saw the tornado approaching, marshaled their charges into the base ment, no child was hurt. The tornado originated near Frank- line, six miles west of Melissa, swept eastward, destroying farm buildings along the way at Boland and Cham- bersvilie, then missed the west side of Melissa, only to sweep down from the east. The 3-year-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wheeler Loftice was killed In her mothers arms by a flying piece of scantling. The mother was not in jured.

document.text: Wheu sheriff Coleman passed out of the building to the broad stone porch, he was accosted by R. H. Browning, and the heated words that ensued soon led to blows, sev eral of which were exchanged. A very few minutes after the difficulty, Field Smith, a well-known resident of Appomattox, denounced the sher iff, and another difficulty was nar rowly averted. Mr. Coleman has been sheriff of Appomattox county for a good many years. He will be opposed in his candidacy for re-election to the office spring after next by Mr. Frank W. McKinney. A gentleman from Appomattox who arrived in the city yesterday said to a reporter of the News that Mr. Coleman had stated to several parties since the political meeting on Thursday, that he was a candidate for the legislature as the floater from Appbmattox and Campbell. Mr. Coleman has been a staunch Democrat for many years, and his action has been a surprise to his many friends. On Friday Mr Coleman told a friend that he was iu the fight and I mean business. The editor of this paper was not present when the altercation between the sheriff and Mr. Browning took place nor when the sheriff announced himself an independent candidate for the House of Delegates, but from the leliable information we liather there seems to be little doubt that the report given of the affair by the News is correct, except that which is corrected by card is this issue.

document.text: When court opened here Monday a large ciowd was present the mat ter of intense interest being the Sears-Ilarvey murder trial. Three Juries and about seventy-five wit nesses had been summoneu by Sher iff McKinney besides these the rel atives and close friends on each side of the unfortunate affair were on hand, and showed as much in terest in the pioceedings as the principals. Mr. Thomas Watkins one of the ablest criminal lawyers of the State has been secured to conduct the case for the Common wealth, who will be aided by that talented young lawyer from Am herst, Mr. Aubrey E. Strode. Con gressman Flood is looking after the defence side of the case. The Grand Jury indicted Sears for murder of Harvey and the prisoner, who was out on bail ap peared in court and answered the indictment. The application for bail was made and the Judge con tinued it until morning on the mo tion of defence, and Sears was plac ed in jail for the night. On Tuesday morning the court beard the evideuce of the defence for the purpose of granting bail, at the conclusion of which the J odge granted bail m the sum of ten thousand dollars for the appear ance of the prisoner on the second day of the next erm of court, which will be the 24th day of July. Sears takes the stand and relates the story of the killing of Harvey, which was substantially as follows I was co lector of taxes my bio- ther was collector, 1 was not old enough, and he qualified and gave me the place he trouble occurred between store and shop 1 first saw Harvey as I was oil my way to col lect some scattering tickets beyond his place I bad collected Harveys ticket 1 was on my way to Dicker- sons I saw Bryant and be told me to come by aud he would pay mt we went together to Rose Bo wet saw Harvey Harvey asked about Woodsons tuxes Harvey asked about bis old ticket and said he hadnt received it I went on and came back to Rose Bower as I ode up Harvey asked if I had seeu Woodson, I said 1 had been toGoiua and would have to get him to send his taxes up to Appomattox he cursed the collector and I told him he was my brother, and he start.-d to nsing oaths again I dropped the matter and inquired the way to Gallegtiers colected Galleghers taxes and cume back to Rote Bow er, and rode up and told Bryant if he was ready we would go up to Vera together. document.text: wheat for many years from present appearances. Corn and oat? are backward. The gardens are good and fried chicken plentiful. Aunt Lucy McKinney, a very worthy colored woman, fell from a cherry tree last Friday, a distance of about sixteen feet, and broke her neck. She lived but a short time. She did not speak after the fall. She was buried to-day. Her childr .it in the North sent a telegram not to bury her until they came. She lived at the Merryman place, immediately op the road from this place to the Court House. The young ladies from Asbury are all at home after a hard years wt.rk. Miss s Lizzie and Hattie Baldwin, Pearl Steger, Julia Payne, Bertha Anderson and Mattie Avery were the contingents f om Bucking ham, with several boy, names not emembered. Mi-s Sarah Ely, a young lady from Kentucky and a student at Asbury. will spend the summer in Virginia as the guest of Miss Julia Payne. She is spending the week at Andersonville. The young ladies from the State Normal are also at home. A goodly number from Buckingham attended that institution. Farmville is a great place. I always had a warm place in my heart for the old town. Oh, my ! how many have passed over the liver since I left there in May, 1859 ! But few now walk its streets who were then at mans estate. 1 can recall Messrs. Meade Davidton. John Walton. Willie Venable, Chas. Erambert, and possibly a few others Messrs. Watt Dunningon, Charlie Walker, Ned Eiagibert and Sam Paulett were themJike myself, on the boy order. How swift time flies! How surely we ought to obey the njunction, Be ye also ready. The Convention in Richmond.the 9th was a very large body of i ,.d len. Virginia has many sons JsjfA roud of. I saw very little drunk enness in the delegation of the many notable men. If a sti anger to all bad to pick out of the big ones from look and speech Montague would te apt to be one of the first. Gen. Booth when asked what be considered to be the chief danger of this country said Religion without the Holy Ghost, Christianity without Christ, forgiveness of sin without re pentance, salvation without regene ration, politics without Cod and heaven without hell. We need big men at the head of affairs like Bryan, Montague and Mann.  The Holiness Camp Meeting will commence the 17th of July. Ample provision to care for man and beast will be made. Our Mr. A. C. Gar- et.t is at the head. He is a man of affaire. Now, brother or sister, what ever denomination come or breathe prayer for its success. Claim the promise, Matt, xviii, 20. Our third Quarterly Conference will be held at Bethel the second Saturday and Sunday in August. The meeting will he continued. Our presiding elder will no doubt have some one to continue with him through the meeting, possibly Rev. T. J. Taylor, of Crewe. The elder may stay over several days. May it be a great spiritual feast and savor of life unto life to many. For fear your readers will say I talk too much I stop with this P. S.Our neighbor and friend, Mr. Jno. Flood, is a very sick man. His Doctor Morrison gives him faithful attention. It is to be hoped that the doctors skill may be sue- s ssful in restoring his health, but with all the skill of the medical fra ternity the human family continues to pass away. Mrs. Ferguson is now on an ex tended visit from Browns to Muddy Creek. How long it will take for her to get around this scribe saith not. Mrs. Mo lie Eppes is still on the rheumatic bed of five years standing, the very embodiment of patience Not a murmur is heard. June 20, 1904.

document.text: We did not, in last weeks issue, give our readers an account of the occurrences at the Spout Spring recinct on election day, because we did not know, when we went to press, the true facts in the case and preferred to say nothing on the sub ject until we were fully informed thereon. We have heard the statements of the three judges and constable, F. Martin, all of which we give as well as the general facts we have gleaned that our readers may draw their own conclusions. The election at this precinct be gan in a quiet and orderly manne with Messrs. Lantech Jones, It. G Whorley and G. W. Diuguid as udges, Mr. F. L. Martin as consta bleand Messrs. F. B. Jones and John Overton as clerks. After nine votes had been regularly polled, negro named Henry Hughes weut into the booth to get Constable Mar tin to fix his ticket. Mr. Martin told him he would assist him by pointing ont the names to him. Thi Mr. Martin d id and poiu ted c u tTren tl name and Floods name both of which he scratched and then pointed out Smiths name which he scratche when the negro stopped and said You have scratched Mr. Colli us name, the very man 1 wanted vote for. The constable replied, You are a d ----- -n liar  if you dont like that ticket get anothe one and fix it to suit yourself. The negro then folded the ticket up and without makiug the slightest com plaint voted it. He weut out and iu about ten minutes Mr. E. F. Col tinswent into the election room and demanded the removal of the con stable, on the ground that he was not treating him fairly. The judges refused to make the removal. After short interval Collins, D. V McKinney and Hughes went int the room and behind them on the porch and on the ground was crowd of between twenty and thirty McKinney in a very excited way de maiided the removal of the consta ble and threatened blood-shed if he was not removed. The judges again refused to remove him, when Me Kinney and his backers grew mor violent. Mr. Diuguid, the liepuii can judge,was m favor of the rernov aud finally Mr. Whorley, because he thought otherwise that violence would be done the constable, advis ed him to leave. This the consta ble refused to do. But Mr. Whor- ieys suggestion to Martin, that lit leave, being construed iuto his con sent to his removal he was hustled out anti a Populist constable putin. At the time of this occurrence there was but one Democrat ou the grounds, besides the election officers. Mr. Martin was not a.new consta ble, but the same one who acted at the same place last Fall and one Whtr gave satisfaction tw-all parties, as is shown by the depositions of Dr. D. Mott Robertson and Mr. E. F. Collins, both of whom testified iu the Yost-Tucker contest, to his fairness and honesty. Here is what the officers of elec tion say about the occurrence. Mr, Lamech Jones appended to the certificate on the poll books the following statement Mr. K. G. Whorley also signed this statement, but later scratched his name off as he was one of the Commissioners of Election. The statement is as follows  As Judges of Election at Spout Spring, at the election held for officers, May 23d, 1895, we wish to make a statement as to the removal of Fitz Lee Martin, the regularly appointed constable.

document.text: Was the mother of 50 years ago a better cook than the mother of today? One glimpse of the tempting array of brBad, cake, doughnuts, pies and cookies exhibited at the Appomattox County Fair, Appo mattox, October 12 to 15, will change your mind if you- think so. Loaves of bread of varying size and quality were made ten or more years ago. They were round oaves and square loaves, flat oaves and tall loaves, little oaves and big loaves, made and aked in a thousand different ways. Visitors to the fair will find that an entirely different kind of oaf is being made today. The modern loaf weighs about a pound and is baked in a tin of standard size. Housewives are using practically the same re cipes. Judges say bread made in this way is much superior. Styles in pies, doughnuts, cakes and cookies have changed just as much in recent years as as they have with bread. Im proved recipes have been worked out in every field by students of cooking and adopted by the American housewife. In fact, judges assert that there isnt a single thing entered in the bak ing exhibit of the fair today which does not score higher than it did a few years ago The Appomattox County Fair is devoting much attention to womens activities. Libera prizes are offered for the best displays of baking, sewing, anc canning. Mrs. Mary McKinney is chairman of the Fancy Work Department Mrs. W. M. Thomp son is chairmah of the Domestic Science department and Mrs. C F. James, is chairman of pickles, preserves, etc- department. The zero

document.text: warm and loving wi Iconic to the Methodist brethern. These services will continue during the months of July and August. Rev. Mr. Little ton also occupied the pulpit and took part in the service. Mr. C. A. Pri-e and family will occupy a portion of the home of Vlrs. Wade for the coming Normal session. There are some 125 students in attendance upon the Summer Nor mal, SO of whom board at the Nor mal, with Mary White Cox ii. charge. Our authorities are urging for new granolithic walkways, aud 1 suppose when they have finished with the town they will begin Work on the public roads leading into, town. The dispensary is au up-to- date road builder, and none of us are  looking the gift horse in the mouth. I feel sympathy for the cooks who have to stand over the cook stove in weather like this, but I am very grateful to them for tneir faithful ness. Mrs. C , R. Morton and her daughter, Miss Loulie, are at Crocketts Springs. Mrs. P. W. McKinney and Miss Frankie, are at Blue Ridge, Supt. Eggleston addressed the Summer Normal on last Thuisday evening aud a reception followed.  Rev. Mr. Matchott, who is sup plying tiie Episcopal pulpit, is preaching most acceptably to mem bers of that congregation. Our livery horses are suffering on the road during the heated term. The soda water man is all smiles with the thermometer in the nine ties. Our doctors are n it busy, the health of our people being unusually good. Our preachers will have their usual vacation. The small boy is enjoying the river, and the older boy the bath rooms. Our fathers little dreamed thai Farmville would one day be sup plied with telephones,electric lights, bath rooms and granolithics, and who ever dreamed that one dispen sary would whip out five saloons ?

document.text: ward LeGrand,  Sr., died very suddenly of heart disease, at his home three miles oast of here. Mr, LeGrand, a few dys before, attempted to hew some rai road ties near his residence, and had the mis fortune to cut his knee very badly with the axe this, however, was net the cause if his death. It has been known for years that his heart wasseriously affected, and while his death was a great shook to . his relatives and friends, they have rather xpected that the end would come sud- lenly. His father and one of iiis brothers jassed away in the same mannerwith, mt a moments warningfrom heart disease. The deceased was 62 years of vge, and had spent his whole life in this his native county. He comes from one of the old Virginia families, and is tho last son of fifteen children horn unto Caroline Hunter and Archer Alex. Lc- ttvand. He connected himself with Lib erty Baptist church when quite a young man _ 45 years ago, and his walk in life has been upright and correct, full of Christian love for his neighbor and fel- lcwman. It is said there are only two other members of Liberty who have wor shipped with the church longer than the deceased,  ind they a-r Messrs. M. H. Golem an and T. H. A. Clieathain. Hu served the Confederacy with distinction to himself and fidelity to the cause. He was several times wounded, and was promoted to theoffice Lieutenant for bravery am.proticcn cy. He has held positions of honor and trust j since the war. the latest position that of Sup- I intcmlcut oi the County Aims House and farm, in all of these positions lii .1 character, shown out as a great power and influence for good. Thirty-six years ago he married Mi6S Sarah Ann Smithsister of T. A. Smith, of this place. As a result of this marriage six child rensurvive him, together with his widow as d II ows ! Mrs. IV. M. Hancock,of this piu.cvj  E. LeGrand, Jr., Evergreen Mrs. W. A. Keilv, Crewe L. B. LeGrand, Lynchburg, Ya. Mis. W. D. Mason, Pam pi in City, and Josiah LeGrand, who remainsst horn. lie. s also survived by live sister Mrs. C. V Hancock, Mrs. C. A. Abbitt, of this place Mrs. S. H. Kelly, of Crewe Mrs. W. H.Iiay- ick, of Washington, D. t, and Mrs. Kh-.h- d Bright, of Kansas City, Mo. His funeral was preached by his pastor, Dr. G. B. Taylor, to a large assemblage of sorrowing friends and relatives in a tender and consoling style, and the interment was had Tuesday evening at Liberty Cemetery in the presence of a large crowd of his old friends. The pall-bearers were J. R. Atwood, K. F. Burke, R. 8. Jenkins, H. W. McKinney, J. F. Dickerson, and Jennings Ferguson. George T. Peers, Jno. G. Fisher and Misses Vera Burke and Virgilia Atwood sang a very appropriate song. The sod never rested over a nobler charuc ter than Ned LeGrand. He w as our friend he was a friend to everybody. There is none to take his place.

document.text: W P re out in full spring dreu, but fact is they dreBS in summer style the year round, and those Easter bonnets some of them bigger than ever, to the horror of all those people who go to cbnrch to see the preacher as well aB hear him. I dare not call it a craze and yet it lookB that way. A factory for the making of candy will soon open in town. If the oparator is fortunate enough to con vert six cents worth of sugar into sixty cents worth of candy he ought to make money. And thats what the city makers do. The macadam between Farmville and Hampden-Sidney is in bad snape, and the neglect ii shameful. Men have always differed, men will continue to differ as long as men live on the earth, and just now Farmville is stirred to the depths on the subject of a site for a new school building. Citizens of the west, end clamor for the new building, and citizen. of the east end make like de bands. llow the question is to b settled remains to be seen. The trouble with all public questions is to get men to deni with them as they do with their own private af fairs. The legislation of I his coun try, national, state, county aud municipal would be vastly improved oi if public agents were as true to public duty, and as sensible in its discharge as when dealing with the private concerns of li e. Ydu tickle me aud I will tickle you has a firm grasp on all public of ficials. Old man Vauderbiit said, Dn the people, and so say the vast majority of those clothed with a little brief authority. At the first touch of spring tae girls came out in full summer dre.-e, and yet the dear creatures know but little of winter wear in these days. White shirt waists aie all the lime in evidence, and there is wide spread horror of overshoes and wrap Gnardiau angels hover over them or first-clsss funerals wonld always be on hand. Mrs. Florida Fitzgerald, who has been ill, is improving. Miss Frankie McKinney is viBit ing frieuds in Richmond. Mr. Beverly Winston, of Lynch bnrg, has been a guest in the old home. Soda fountains have taken on new life and the ioe man wears a broad tmile. No fruit blossoms as yet, and it is hoped they will remain in winter quarters until it is safe to emerge.

document.text: w . Harvey Shoots F. L. Martin in the Arm . Saturday evening the largest crowd ever seen on the base ball field here assembled to witness the national game between Concord and Appomattox. A large crowd of ladies and children were in atten dance, many of them from Coucord and other far off places. The game was probably the most interesting one ever played here, as the teams were evenly matched and at the end of the seventh inning the score stood 5 ,o 2 iu favor of Concord. At this stage of the game a pistol shot was heard in the middle of the crowd, which caused a stampede among the ladies and children. C. W. Harvey, of Spring Mills, shot and wounded F. L. Martin, who lives uear this place. At the time of the shootiug it was thought by many that Martin was mortally wounded, for Harvey, n less than ten feet apparently took deliberate aim at his bosum, but upon examination, his wound proved to be only a flesh wound in the left arm. Constable F. W. McKinney and other gentlemeu grabbed Har ey and placed him under arrest tud disarmed him before he could hoot again. Harvey was given a hearing before Justice Trent he waived an examination and was  laced tinder bond for his appear ance at the next term of the county court in the sum of 1000. Iu talking to the T im es  man about the affair Harvey said he was a pro fessional shot, and would not allow any man to run over him. Stated that he shot to keep Martin off of him and that Martin had struck him with brass knucks. Martin said that Harvey had assaulted him some fifteen minutes before by knocking up against him and curs iug him, blit his friends took him off and lie thought no more abou the matter until Harvey approached him in the crowd aud cursed him again, when he Martin struck him with his list and knocked him down friends took hold of Martin when llarvey got on his feet he drew his pistol and fired into the crowd There are a great many conflicting reports about the affair, no two of which seem to agree exactly, but the people who saw the affair are strong in their condemnation of a drunken man shooting into a crowd of help less women and children. It is said that both men had been drinking some and that Harvey bad assaulted several people on the grounds before he got into the troublewith Martin. Both are young men of good quali ties and while Harvey bears the eputation of being a desperate man while under the influence of liquor, he is peaceable and highly respected sober. Our town generally and especially the lovers of base call regret very much that such an affair should occur here in our usually quiet village, and it may be said that the low-abiding citizens of the commu nity will applaud the action of our public officers in their efforts at preserving the peace and bringing the guilty ones to a strict account ability in all cases like this. But for the prompt action of our officers and by standers, who disarmed Har vey many innocent people might have been killed and a general riot prccipated, as both men had many friends on the grounds.

document.text: Virginia Cavalry, the late Governor Phil. McKinney being captain .of the company, and although I knew nothing of the war from personal experience, 1 enjoyed on num berless occasions hearing from the lips of Doc Carter, Ned Steger, Billy Davis, Tom Garnett and others graphic accounts of the deeds of valor and narrow escapes of Co. K, and wheu death came to the old- soldier it was gratifying to his widow and children to have him borne to his grave by six of his old comrades in arms, viz., C., Y. Hooper, E. Vao Anderson, Tom W. Garnett, E. J. Steger, W. H. Davis and J. Bnsh Gray, and the minister who conduct ed the burial services was also an old Co., K comradeRev. John Spencer, of the court bouse. Mr. Carter leaves a widow to whom he had been married 59 years, one son and five daughters, aud he ieaves a name of unsullied integrity. In 1889 he made a profession of religion in the New Store church,,and on the same occasion three other residents near ing their three score years, who had lived, like Mr. Carter, figureaively within the shadow of the church building ail their lives, but who up to that time had been worldly,pio- fane and reckless and indifferent to the future lifemade like profe sion, and I may say of Mr. Carter aud the whole neighborhood wi endorse it, that he evidently was born again, he was a new man iu Christ Jesus. His totally changed life was patent to all. He was member of Concord Baptist church And 79 years old.

document.text: Very soon after the voting com menced, Henry Hughes, a negro, applied for a ticket to vote and ask ed the constable to aid him. With the constable he entered the booth, returned and deposited the ballot and went out of doors and in a few miputes, I think after one vote had been oast, E. F. Collins came iuto the room and said they demanded their rights in a loud aud excited manner and stated the constable had improperly scratched the name of E. F. Collins from the ticket voted by said Hughes and demanded his removal. We ordered them from the room and refused to remove the said constable. They then left then after one vote was cast, the said Collins, McKinney and Hughes again enter-ed the room, a large an d ex cited crowd following them to the house, some coming on the porch and some stood around the porch aud Collins and McKinney very ex citedly again demanded the consta bles removal. Mr. Jones believing the constable was performing his duty properly again refused and said to the other judges they could do as they dleased, he would not con sent to the removal. The said con stable was removed and Eldridge Carson appointed in his place. We are satisfied that by the removal of the said Martiu as constable and the

document.text: Two M en M eet on th e Old Court H ouse R oad -W ord s are E x changedP istols B raw n and a Constable W ounded. On Tuesday last about 12 or 1 oclock, a shooting affray occurred on the road leading to the Old Court House, between Messrs. Prank W. McKinney and Elijah Fore. The scene of the quarrel was in the neigh borhood of Galilee Church, and re sulted in McKinneys receiving a painful though not serious wound through the leg jnst above the knee. The cause of the difficulty seems to have beeu as follows Mr. Mc Kinney, as constable, was cojnmis- sioned to collect from Mr. Fore a bill due to a firm in Lynchburg. Fore refused to pay the amount declaring that the debt was unfair. McKin ney then receiving an indemnifying bond and taking, as he states, every precautionary measure to render his ictions justifiable in the eyes of the law, proceeded to levy upon Fores goods. He employed James Harvey to assist him in removing the property, On his way to Fores Store, the place of residence of Fore, he met that gentleman on his way to appomat tox Depot. Some words ensued then and Fore declared that nothing should force him to submit to being levied upon. They separated and McKinney proceeded to Fores Store and having levied upon the goods, loaded them into a wagon and set out for home. He instructed Jim Harvey not to have a word to say to Fore and to give him the road. Har vey advised McKinney that he had better be careful himseif. In the meantime Fore had reached Appomattox and found some arti cles which he had expected to ship had been attaohed and were in the possession of the law. After trans acting his business at this place, he, too, started on his return trip, Fores young son was with him, and, we think, was driving a one-horse wagon. The two parties met just below magistrate Dnrrums near Galilee Church,- and as there has been no official investigation we will give aB near as possible the state ments of both. Mr. McKinney states in brief.  saw Fore coming down the road anc. knowing that he was anxious to pick a quarrel would have done anything to have avoided i t  but as there was no way to escape meeting  him, drove on, turning out and giving hii the entire road. I had passed him and driven on about twenty yards when he turned and said Mr. McKinney you are too quick in your levies. I will teach you some sense that will benefit you in the future. I replied, Very well Mr. Fore I will be very glad to re ceive any lesson. I then started on but was again stopped and turning saw Fore shaking his fist at me while he exclaimed,  You rogue yon scoundrel, you might just as well have entered my house and stolen the goods. This was too much for human nature to submit to. I turned my jumper, rode up to him and dis mounting asked what he meant by insulting me. He was about to re peat his language when I hit him over the head with the butt end of my whip. His horse became fright ened and nearly threw Fore from the wagon. He righted himself and then I whipped him again. The horse for the second time started down the road and again nearly upset the wagon. It went about fifteen yards. I made towards Fore again. Dont you come here, he cried I still ad vanced and he cried again Dont come any nearer, dont come any nearer. I noticed that his hand was on his pistol pocket, and walking up to him I said Mr. Fore, you can shoot me if you want to, but I have whipped yon enough, and dont propose to hit you another time
